contents: <sup>7</sup>The “ingredients” of a eureka moment often involve relaxation and a lack of focus. <sup>8</sup>Prevailing theories suggest that by not thinking directly about a problem, one is able to see the challenge from different angles and without the restrictions that may have been preventing problem-solving in the first place. <sup>9</sup>This is why eureka moments often happen in the shower, while driving, or during other transitional moments. <sup>10</sup>While Archimedes couldn’t solve his problem when considering it directly, he was in a relaxed mindset while stepping into the bath. <sup>11</sup>This distraction opened his mind to an alternative solution, and he had one of the most  famous “aha!” moments in history. <sup>12</sup>So if you’re ever working on a difficult problem, maybe the best thing to do is step away, relax, and let your mind look at things from a different perspective.
